title: What is the purpose of alchemy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Alchemy is a spiritual practice involving the transmutation of low vibration to high vibration. “Lead” and “gold” are metaphorical states of being, with “lead” being the lowest state and “gold” being the highest state. Think of the archetypical Hero’s Journey. The hero usually starts out in a “low” state of some kind. Maybe they’re just an average human who feels like they can’t make a difference in the world, or stuck in the grind of everyday life, or stuck in a bad life circumstance, or emotionally devastated, etc. Throughout their adventure and the various encounters that they have, they change. The hero usually ends their journey in a state of perfection or even divinity, experiencing a literal or figurative apotheosis (sometimes involving a return from death), and they are often more powerful, more mature, and more self-aware than they were. This is transmutation. Somehow, I came upon the realization that the experience of living is transmutation — we are all, in the course of our lives, seeking to obtain some elusive state of “purity,” whether that be divinity or moral goodness or power or heaven after death. We all want to bring ourselves up. I believe that we are here on this earth because the experiences we have in life, no matter how plagued with suffering they may be, are designed to further the growth of our souls over the course of many lifetimes until we reach a state of divinity, perfection, nirvana. Alchemy is the meaning of life. Yeah, I realize I just said that. As for what that transmutation really consists of, I think it’s a number of things. Self-knowledge in particular is incredibly important, at least in my opinion. Reconciling the dualities inherent in the self is part of that. Also part of that is clearing spiritual baggage that’s holding you back, which is a lot easier said than done. The self-knowledge part is easy for me by now, but transmuting the unnecessary suffering that I inflict upon myself is harder, even though it seems like it would be easier. I still don’t really get practical alchemy. I have a book on it, and I keep meaning to really go through it and attempt to make sense of it. Maybe practical alchemy is just a tool, a physical anchor that one can attach one’s spiritual practice to, in order to make it more concrete. It’s always easier to interact with something tangible rather than intangible. But I’m going to stay far away from anything involving mercury — my mother played with raw mercury on her hands back before its dangers were known, and now I’ve got loads of mercury in my bloodstream that I’m trying to get rid of. Oh well. Maybe I’ll experiment with practical alchemy eventually, once I actually know more about Hermeticism, but I think that what really matters is the spiritual aspect of it.

Alchemy is a Western meditative practice akin to chakra exploration. I rate it as no more and no less ‘valid’ than chakra work. Good for getting your feet wet and learning to appreciate the subtleties of inner mental states. But not quite at the level of the Law of Attraction or Intention / Manifestation. The latter two have you actually affect the world through your actions and will. Alchemy / Chakras, when done properly, allow you to gently find an inner equilibrium and can serve as an excellent jumping off point for more ‘serious’ spiritual practice. I could scour Amazon for a ‘decent’ alchemy book to start with, but honestly you can do this yourself. Just go to a bookstore or library, and start looking through the books that interest you. One of them will reach out and ‘grab’ you. That’s the one you want. When I was younger we didn’t have this magical Internet thing to tell us the ‘right’ way to do things. You just had to make do with your intuition and, if you were lucky, a local teacher. I had both, and I have to say, one’s own intuition is the best possible guide.
